1)  Lingering Song / Curse Song feats.  I'm not sure about these, as most of the bard levels are going to come so late.  Maybe extra music and something else instead and just use lich lyrics to burn the songs?  I'm not sure which feats would be worthwhile if I drop these.

2)  What to do with the 18 extra skill points that I can't start using until level 18?  I was thinking I would just boost lore, not sure anything else will be useful that late in the game.

3)  Greatsword good for this build?  I thought about dropping toughness and the two song feats and dual-wielding shortswords instead ( jergal's sword in SoU :D).  Not sure which is better.  I did not want to do sword/shield as I just ran a rogue/fighter/bg through the oc with that setup (although by mid-chapter 2 he was quite powerful).  I decided to use taunt on this character because my BG got some mileage out of it when he came up on the odd high armor class opponent.

4)  Any spell suggestions?  I figured ultravision/darkness might be useful late, especially since darkness and displacement can be cast in armor (before engagement, I plan on just melee with knockdown for casters once the fighting starts).  Summon Creature I would be for baiting traps (I'm evil after all).  I'm not really wild about buff spells for the most part.  Since the bard levels are coming so late I probably won't get too much use out of these.

5)  Any other suggestions?  The last time I did SoU and went on to HotU was with a bard / fighter / harper scout and it was a terrible character which is probably why I gave up on HotU so quickly.  I don't remember SoU being difficult and even that terrible character finished without issues but it seems the difficulty ramps up in HotU.

I appreciate any advice.  I will likely use Dorna/Deekin in SoU and some kind of rogue companion in HotU, given my deficiency of dealing with traps.  It was funny though, in the OC my BG could open almost any lock and disarm all the traps, by chapter 3 he would just walk through them and bash chests because it was quicker (sooo many chests).  With evasion he rarely took damage from traps.

Ignore singing and limit spellcasting to scrolls, wands, rods and other items.

Play this as a pure warrior with some UMD.  It doesn't matter that much which hench is used in SoU.  Dorna will manipulate traps and Xanos will spam Find Traps.  Can't recall what Deekin does in SoU but I know he won't ID loot until HotU.

The trick is: finishing SoU by no higher than Level 13 so you can command HotU Deekin to train as pure bard.  That way he'll get Lasting Inspiration and uber skill boost for your skill checks (especially Appraise and Persuade).  If he gets even one level as RDD he will never take LI.  

There are no dedicated trap handlers for HotU after Ch 1 so you'll be forcing them yourself (all traps) and using your HP total to absorb all damage.  Just be careful of stunning/draining effects when foes are nearby (i.e. force them while invisible).

Your taunts will cause AoOs so get in the habit of using Expertise mode when using the skill.

IMO, if you are committed to DevCrit (which you seem to be), choose the widest crit range weapon possible (martial: scimi, exotic: kukri) because the keen prop in HotU Ch2 will make the biggest difference.  Else, with a 2H weapon, use those feats for more STR and make a damage adept instead.  DevCritters should always use the best critting weapons available (although monk DevCritters use APR instead of crit range).

Cautionary note:

Please examine the completed builds section closer for how they are formatted for ease of inspection.  Your level-up schedule is unnecessarily difficult to follow with the class split instead of level sequence.  The skills allocation and stats are fine, though.

If you can find the time, why not formally introduce yourself?  It will not only help us to understand your playstyle but get a glimpse of your background, hobbies, gripes... ...you know the drill.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I don't think the wings will show through armor anyway but I haven't played an RDD in a VERY long time so maybe they do.  Empyre (our ECB RDD specialist) will correct me if I am mistaken, but I think the breath weapon can be used in Expertise mode just like Shifter wyrmling.

Bard doesn't perform the UMD hardcore scroll check so all you need is enough modified ranks to accommodate the scroll's value and then you can use it without failure and that's mostly for divine scrolls/wands since bard can use most of the arcane stuff by default.  For example, a scroll of Mord or SoV is valued about 5.5k gold so with UMD 10, you can use values up to 10k gold.  If you decide on class-specific gear you may need a bit more, i.e. UMD 15 is good up to 100K. If so, pull from Discipline because your STR cap will more than compensate for the 5 points.

Mainly I'd focus on scrolls like NegNRG Prot and Shadow Shield to help free up gear slots to cap abilities.  You should be able to easily cap STR @46 (+18 * 150%) and perhaps even some +CON wouldn't hurt your HP and Fort saves.

If you really prefer a 2H weapon, a Greataxe would look more racially-correct, I suppose.  The x3 crits will look impressive when they hit with all that STR.  Keened with ImpCrit you'll reach a 17-20 range.

Elves will have less of a HP pool to stand there and take damage, though.  With a 1H weapon and the added shield AC it wouldn't be so bad but you'll be wanting Fort as high as possible against most death-like spells.  Mind immunity items abound so Will is not a factor in HotU.  The Shield scroll will protect against MM spams.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
mitspieler wrote:
-  I didn't like delaying the last two RDD levels to epic.  I know that costs me one BAB from the 9th level of RDD, delaying my 4th attack by one level, and ultimately costing me one attack bonus (at the time I pick up the last RDD level in epic levels).  I think I would rather have the 4 strength, 1 armor class, and immunities from level 16 on than have one more attack bonus on the last couple of levels that I play this character.  Too bad I can't scream at my henchmen to cast fireballs at me!
No worries.  As long as you recognize the consequences for your decisions there will be no surprises.  You do get some extra skill points in exchange for that AB so it's not a total bust.
-  I moved the bard levels around to enjoy the spellcraft and tumble bonuses a little more through the life of the character.  I'm probably not going to get much use out of taunt it appears, unless I give up tumble or spellcraft early instead.
I'm betting you'll be wanting it for the Expertise/Taunt combo since your AC is going to suffer with two hands tied to a weapon.  If you manage the full bonus, you'll get that AB back that was lost from shift of RDD levels and boost your AC in the bargain.  Just don't try taunting mages.  You may get lucky vs. them but their concentration will probably be substantially higher than your skill (the main reason I selected the associated skill focus... to get a 15% better chance to beat those types which is really tough/lucky).
-  I am pretty set on using a big stick, so I moved away from devastating critical since there are no big sticks with extended threat ranges.  This changed the feat selection a bit.  I'm not sure if there is more to playing a "damage adept" than just taking Great Strength feats at epic levels.  I looked around the build forums some but I didn't really see high strength builds that didn't select the devastating critical feat.
DevCrit is popular because it looks impressive against hordes of easy-to-hit rabble.  I have a personal dislike for Great Cleave because I've found myself locked into the animation when I needed to pull away beyond an AoE spell and couldn't.  Almost got me killed on a number of occasions.  Some folks just like to watch that whirlwindy type animation regardless of consequences, though.
18 - Ftr(5): Toughness    (or Disarm)
19 - Ftr(6): Called Shot  (or ImpDisarm)
Since you've dumped the skill focus and Great Cleave, and are holding a large weapon, Improved Disarm could prove to be lots of fun against all those drow with shortswords and daggers and any other holders of smallish weaponry.  But it's your choice.  I penciled it in as a viable alternate.  Make sure to take both if you decide to go that route. Note that Called Shots will not affect skins with freedom like driders and beholders or creatures w/o arms have so don't waste your attempts on them.
AC (naked/mundane fplate): 16/24
Actually... AC w/mundate fplate is:   10base +6tum +4rdd +2as +8fplate = 30 and I suspect the error pleases you.

Let's see... at STR 36, the cap will yield STR 48 which will be 19 * 150% = [28 slashing dmg + (1-12 base)] x3 crit = 87- 120 per crit.  5 APR, hasted. Not bad at all for a level 28 toon.
